_emerg_resp.FR_OtherRegulation: ILLINOIS DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE ANHYDROUS REGULATION

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Facility:    BAYHILL FERTIOLIZER INC.

                            Contact:    Bill Harfst

                            Manager:    Dave Harfst

                            Phone 309-537-3188

        
                 1.  Facility Policy:   The  owner , management, and employees of  Bayhill Fertilizer are committed to the prevention of any accidential releases of anhydrous ammoia by utilization of proper equipment, regular inspection and maintence and training of all personal that work with the material. Should an accidental release occur the orientated the local fire department and the local emergency planning committee so the plan for response to any release and minimize the inpact of the release to people and the environment.

               2.       Facility information:    The primary activity at the facility is storage of fertilizer for sale to farmer.Anhydrous ammonia is received, stored and distributed for direct application as a NUTRIRNT for crop production.The maximun quantity stored would be 385,000 pounds in storage tanks and nurse tanks.

                 3.       Worse-case Scenario and Alternate Release Scenario:   The worse case release scenario would be the release of the total content of one of the storage tank release as a gas over 10 minutes. The maximum quinity release would be 71,450 pounds, which represents the volume of one of the storage tank at 85 persent capacity as limited by design standard and company procedures. The distance to the endpoint of dispersion base on the model used is .94 miles.

                         The alternative case release scenario is assumed to be release from a rupure of a 1 inch trasfer hose , with 2900 pounds release over 2 minutes. The distance to the endpoint of dispersion is .31 miles.

                4.        The accidental release program:    The facility complies with the Rules and Regulations related to handling of Anhydrous Ammonia an

d Low Pressure Nitrogen Solution, Containters and Storage Facilities. These regulation administered by the Illinois Department of Agriculture are conistent with OHSA 29 CFR 1910.111 regarding storage and handling of anhydrous ammonia.

                5.         The Five-year Accident History:        There has been NO accendental release of anhydrous ammonia for the last five years that has cause deaths, injuries, evacuation, shelter in place, property damage or envirenmental damage. None to our knowledge.

                 6.         The Emergency Response Program:    The facility has a written emjergency action plan in accordance with OHSA standard 29 CFR 1910.38. Provide state and local authorities the emergency planning and community righ-to-know information as required under SARA Title III of EPCRA. Our emergency response action plan has been review with the local fire department and coordination into community responseplanning.
                                     If a large release of anhydrous take place at the facility, the required response action is to evacuate the area of spill and call 911 and applicable emergency response number.
                                    1. Within 15 minutes of determining the amount of the release would be over 100 pounds, the Emergency Coordinator will be notify.
                                         The National Emergency Response Center Number is 800-424-8802
                                    2. Within 1 hour of determining the amount of release would the envirement , the Emergency Coordinator will notify:
                                The Illinois Environmental Management Agency @ 800-782-7860 in state or 217-782-7820 out of state.

                   7. Planning Changes to improve safety:   Safety improvement is an on going process at the facility. Periodic evaluation are performed to assess the condition of THE FACILITY>  There are no additional specific safety recommendations regarding storage or use of anhydr
ous ammonia ror implementation at this time.
